He may only be a junior in high school, but a Schoharie student who is in the Capital Region BOCES Diesel Tech program is using his skills in a professional setting alongside veteran mechanics and equipment operators.

Jacob Newell is working in the Albany City Heavy Vehicle Repair Shop and the city landfill, using the skills he is learning at BOCES in the real world setting of city equipment maintenance.

Newell said he is enjoying the opportunity.

“Working there is fun and I get to learn a lot about diesel trucks and some of the common parts that break, how to fix them and the ways to diagnose which part actually has a problem and how to fix it,” he said.

Great job Jacob! The photos are of him working at BOCES with other students before the COVID-19 crisis.

We're going to have a little throwback to earlier in the school year.

We had two eighth grade students Braeden Beck and Andrew Martin from Schoharie Central School audition and be accepted into the American Choral Directors Association 2020 Eastern Region Junior High Honor Choir. Students had to record and send in multiple audio files and lengthy applications to be considered.

After their acceptance they traveled to Rochester in early March and spent four days learning music to perform in a culminating concert in Eastman's Kodak Hall at the Eastman School of Music. Braeden and Andrew sang with more than a hundred students from Maine, Pennsylvania, Delaware, New Jersey and all the other northeastern states.

They sang under the direction of Lynnel Joy Jenkins and learned music in multiple genres and languages.

Braeden and Andrew represented Schoharie with pride. Great job!

Our students who attended included Sam Meyer-Veen, Britney Beisly, David St. George, Isabella Haley, Ashli Palmatier, Tori Harrington, Wesly Lee and Gavin Phillips.

“People fear what they can’t understand,” St. George said.

Schoharie's seventh grade class recently went to NYC to view some sights and to see the exhibit "Auschwitz: Not so long ago. Not so far away" a traveling exhibit on display at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in Lower Manhattan. Students went on an educational tour, learned about the Holocaust and saw artifacts from Anne Frank's home, Auschwitz and other concentration camps.

After their tour students had the pleasure of hearing from Ruth Gruener, a Holocaust survivor and author from Lvov (Lemberg), Poland. She shared many experiences from her time in hiding as a young girl. The students were very moved by her story and were able to ask her questions during her presentation

This trip coincides with our new Cultural Awareness course, a class that each seventh grader has for a quarter of the year and was a great lesson about what can happen when people fail to value the differences in others.

Second grade co-teachers Raquel Ackert and Megan Langan lead their class through a Halloween-themed activity this morning. Students learned the difference between liquids and solids and had some fun.

After more than a year of research, planning and training, the district in September implemented co-teaching in grades 2 through 8.

“Co-teaching is a model where we have a special educator and a general educator in a room at the same time with the expectation that the special ed teacher is helping with all of the students,” said Matthew Wright, director of curriculum and pupil personnel services.

The former model involved separate classrooms and/or consultant teachers pushing into multiple classrooms, with some students attending mainstream classes with their peers. This system was less inclusive and involved less exposure to grade-level content, according to Wright.

post_text:
Voters approved the proposed $24,520,229 budget for the 2019-20 school year by a vote of 308 to 108, which is a 74 percent approval. They also approved propositions to purchase school buses, vans and a Suburban and levy taxes for the Schoharie Free Library.

District residents re-elected Terry Burton and Daniel Guasp to the Board of Education and elected Tara Barton to her first term on the Board.

Details at www.schoharieschools.org

Thank you to all who cast their ballots.

post_text: Students in our Travel Club are seeing the world. During the recent spring break, they spent over 10 days in Ireland, Wales, England and Scotland seeing sights such as the Ring of Kerry, Dublin, the birthplace of William Shakespeare, London, Westminster Abby, Edinburgh and Sterling Castle. The students also visited an Irish sheep farm, attended an Irish music and dance show, visited the Queen of England’s home at Windsor Castle and took a trip to the Scottish highlands.

post_text:
News from our music teachers: "We have a new member of the music department at Schoharie!," said Carrie Styles. "An anonymous donor graciously provided us with funds to replace our old upright piano. We were in desperate need of a new piano, as the one we'd been using was literally on its last leg and no longer had a good tone. We are humbled and excited to have a beautiful looking and sounding instrument." Addition of the Kawai piano, which had just one previous owner, now allows SCS's old Baldwin to retire from service.

But that's not all. The new piano will have company.

"As part of the anonymous donor funds for the upright piano, we also will be receiving a new bass clarinet," said SCS music teacher Cassandra Olin. "It will replace an instrument that has been well beyond repair for years, and will allow students who play the bass clarinet to each have their own specific instrument. The instrument has been ordered, and we are currently awaiting its delivery," Olin added. "We are so very grateful for this donation!"
